docs.lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl who complained to school officials yesterday that she was not feeling well later admitted that she had given birth and led officials to her dead infant, which was found in a sewer near her home, the police said. Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, said that it was not clear whether the infant, whose body was found at the corner of 215th Street and 111th Avenue in Queens Village, was born alive, and that an autopsy would be performed today. The girl, meanwhile, was taken to Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, where she was listed in stable condition.
docs.abstract: Unidentified 15-year-old girl who complained to school officials that she was not feeling well and later admitted that she had given birth leads officials to her dead infant, which is found in sewer near her home in Queens Village (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Buchanan gazes approvingly from a framed photograph on Charles M. Condon's office wall. ''To Charlie Condon,'' reads the inscription, ''who is saving lives while others prattle on about the rights of drug addicts.''

headline.main: Defender of God, South and Unborn

docs.abstract: Interview with Charles M Condon, outspoken Attorney General of South Carolina, who is best known for prosecuting pregnant crack cocaine addicts for child abuse and even manslaughter; he has also attacked video poker, refused to swear in an atheist justice of the peace and firmly supports Citadel's fight to bar female cadets; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The tiniest of the quintuplets born last week to a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, couple died before dawn yesterday, as his brother and three sisters, all weighing less than two pounds, battled for their lives at a hospital. The quintuplets' father, Chaim Schnitzler, said at a news conference that his wife, Miriam, a 22-year-old immigrant from Antwerp, Belgium, had been taking fertility drugs. He declined to offer details, but David Pollock, a spokesman for the Jewish Community Relations Council, which is assisting the family, said the couple had been trying, in vain, to have children since they were married two and a half years ago.

headline.main: Brooklyn Quintuplet Dies as His Siblings Struggle to Stay Alive

docs.lead_paragraph: Concluding a six-month review of charges of sex discrimination in Mexico, the United States Labor Department reported today that thousands of border assembly plants administer medical tests to weed out pregnant applicants and harass pregnant workers to coerce their resignation. Others simply dismiss pregnant workers to avoid paying maternity benefits, the department said.

headline.main: Sex Bias Is Reported by U.S. At Border Plants in Mexico

docs.abstract: US Labor Department concludes six-month review of charges of sex discrimination in Mexico, concluding that thousands of border factories administer medical tests to weed out pregnant applicants and harass pregnant workers to coerce their resignation and that others simply dismiss pregnant workers to avoid paying maternity benefits; US Labor Sec Alexis Herman files protest with Mexican counterpart, Javier Bonilla Garcia and requests consultations; review is in response to complaints by Human Rights Watch and other American and Mexican rights and labor groups under terms of side accord to North American Free Trade Agreement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A LARGE study has found that the use of home fetal monitors fails at its intended purpose: to prevent women at high risk of premature labor from giving birth too early. Each year, doctors prescribe such monitors to thousands of pregnant women to detect uterine contractions, which are often signs of early labor. The devices, which are strapped around the abdomen, are used daily for up to 10 weeks at a cost of about $30 to $100 a day. Women believed to be in early labor are then admitted to the hospital and given medicine to stop the contractions.

headline.main: No Benefit Found for Fetal Monitors

docs.abstract: Large study finds that use of home fetal monitors fails at its intended purpose: to prevent women at high risk of premature labor from giving birth too early; study discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine a more destructive idea for the Republican Party than a litmus test on late-term abortion. Yet anti-abortion forces will be pushing a resolution at the Republican National Committee meeting this week that would bar the national party from supporting any candidate who opposed a ban on a procedure critics call ''partial birth'' abortion. The resolution, if passed, would essentially banish pro-choice Republicans and destroy any semblance of a ''big tent'' approach to party-building. Jim Nicholson, who is chairman of the R.N.C. and opposes the measure, will have to persuade conservative members that such a test would be folly. The abortion procedure in question, medically known as intact dilation and extraction, is used only after the first trimester of pregnancy and accounts for just 3,000 to 5,000 of the 1 million abortions performed annually in this country. But anti-abortion groups have grabbed this issue because it is easier to fight a single procedure than to attack constitutionally protected abortion rights in general. The resolution, sponsored by Tim Lambert, a Republican national committeeman from Texas, takes a new twist on this strategy. It would punish Republican candidates who think that a medical decision about a specific procedure should be left to the patient and her doctor.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Republican Party to reject proposal by anti-abortion forces that would bar national party from supporting any candidate who opposes a ban on late-term abortions; says it threatens they very idea of party's big-tent inclusiveness (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON A CROWDED CHRISTMAS shopping day, Barbara Fincher and her sister politely vied for space with another determined shopper at the ''X-Files'' shelf of an independent bookstore in suburban Louisville, Ky. Ms. Fincher, 55, has been a self-described ''X-phile'' for the last year and a half. ''We like the show because so much of it is about Government experimentation on people,'' she explained, noting a parallel with her volunteer work at a pregnancy center and her support of Human Life International, a ''birth spacing'' organization. ''H.L.I. investigates what's going on throughout the world, and how our Government, especially, is involved in population control. Like Scully was kidnapped, but it wasn't by aliens. It was by the Government, who managed to extract all her eggs in order to create some sort of beings.''

headline.main: Confused or Not, the X-Philes Keep Coming

docs.abstract: X-Files television program in its 5th season, keeps building its fan base; attracts fans with rather nonlinear plot line dealing with mutants and monsters, paranormal activity and aliens and UFOs; plot background reviewed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: I'M pro-choice,'' Leslie Singman says. ''Always was and always will be.'' Mrs. Singman, a 35-year-old saleswoman from Potomac, Md., grew up believing that no child should be an unwanted child. She sends money to the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League, and never thought to question her views -- until she got pregnant and saw her daughter on the ultrasound screen. There, in fuzzy black and white, floating in her mother's womb at 16 weeks' gestation, was the tiny but perfectly formed fetus that would become Leah Shayne Singman. ''I could see fingers and toes and the shape of her head and the body,'' Mrs. Singman says. ''I could see bones in her hands, a hand waving at me. It made me think that there is definitely a life growing there.''

headline.main: The Nation; Shifting Certainties In the Abortion War

docs.abstract: Hardened political oratory over abortion has masked fact that modern medicine has irrevocably altered moral landscape surrounding debate as country approaches 25th anniversary of Roe v. Wade; conviction is being challenged by technology, and many who once thought beliefs about abortion were unshakeable are reevaluating and drawing conclusions that reflect shades of gray; fact that even tiniest baby can now survive has made abortion less palatable to some, while making it more palatable to others; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Governor Whitman's inauguration approaches, she is being attacked on both the national and the local fronts for her decision last year to veto state legislation banning what opponents call partial birth abortion. A group of Catholics who oppose abortion have called on Archbishop Theodore McCarrick to bar Mrs. Whitman from using the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark for an interfaith prayer service before her inauguration on Jan. 20.

headline.main: Wherever Whitman Goes, Abortion Debate Follows

docs.abstract: Jennifer Preston column notes that as Gov Christine Todd Whitman's inauguration approaches, she is being attacked on national and local fronts for her decision in 1997 to veto legislation in New Jersey banning what opponents call partial birth abortion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Can free manicures and the lure of cold cash keep teen-age girls from getting pregnant? Gil Burnett, a retired trial judge from New Hanover County, N.C., thinks it's worth a try. Frustrated by 23 years of punishing crimes whose ''root cause,'' he says, was unwanted pregnancy, Burnett is pushing a plan called Project for Happier Lives, which would entice young women to stay un-pregnant through cash sweepstakes. Under it, any girl age 10 to 19 could enroll in three years of monthly classes in money management, career planning and (the crux) saying no to sexual advances, a subject Burnett has dubbed ''Games Guys Play 101.'' For staying un-pregnant, each girl would get the chance to win monthly drawings of $25 gifts (for hairdos and the like) and a $5,000 grand prize at the end of the year. Though the community has agreed that the program makes sense, there has been pointed opposition to the idea that society can buy good behavior. Burnett, who characterizes himself as a die-hard realist, argues that the plan is an unusual but reasonable technique for a county that had 200 teen-age pregnancies in 1996. At the moment, the county commission has stalled on whether to allow the health department to offer official support, but Burnett is steaming ahead with more than $15,000 in private financing and a vision of the project being replicated nationwide. Meanwhile, Burnett's supporters are not moved by the argument that purchased virtue is a vice.
docs.abstract: Gil Burnett, retired North Carolina judge, is pushing plan to encourage young women not to get pregnant by offering prizes in monthly cash sweepstakes; drawing (S)
